chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation
sanskrit:
स्वभावजेन कौन्तेय निबद्धः स्वेन कर्मणा |
कर्तुं नेच्छसि यन्मोहात्करिष्यस्यवशोऽपि तत् ||
transliteration:
svabhāvajena kaunteya nibaddhaḥ svena karmaṇā |
kartuṁ necchasi yanmohātkariṣyasyavaśo'pi tat ||
translation: O son of Kunti, bound by your own nature-born action, that which through delusion you do not wish to do, you will do even against your will.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna delivers a profound truth about the power of one's inherent nature (svabhava) and accumulated tendencies. He addresses Arjuna's reluctance to fight, explaining that despite his mental resistance born of delusion (moha), his warrior nature (kshatriya dharma) will inevitably compel him to act according to his innate disposition. The verse emphasizes that one cannot escape one's fundamental nature simply through wishful thinking or emotional resistance.

This teaching is particularly significant in the context of Chapter 18, where Krishna is bringing together all the major themes of the Gita. He is showing Arjuna that trying to avoid action through false renunciation is futile. The karmic impressions (samskaras) and one's constitutional nature are powerful forces that will assert themselves regardless of superficial desires to the contrary. Krishna is essentially saying that Arjuna's warrior nature, cultivated through lifetimes and reinforced by his training and position, will inevitably drive him to fight.

The philosophical significance lies in understanding that true freedom comes not from suppressing one's nature, but from aligning with dharma while maintaining inner detachment. Rather than being controlled unconsciously by one's nature through delusion, one should consciously fulfill one's dharma with wisdom and surrender to the Divine. This verse serves as a warning against self-deception and highlights the importance of self-knowledge and acceptance of one's svadharma.
speaker: Krishna
